aws::graph::propositions: # Mooney M20TN Aircraft Incident in Adrian, Michigan
The incident occurred in Adrian, Michigan.
The incident occurred on July 27, 2012, at 08:46 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a MOONEY AIRPLANE COMPANY, INC. M20TN.
The defining event of the incident was an inflight upset.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN12FA487.
The aircraft registration was N411JL.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries to the sole occupant.
The pilot reported the airplane experienced a "violent pitch-up" without warning.
The violent pitch-up occurred while the airplane was climbing through flight level 180.
The autopilot was engaged when the violent pitch-up occurred.
The pilot required extreme forward yoke pressure to prevent the airplane from pitching up and stalling.
The pilot estimated between 100 and 150 pounds of force was needed on the yoke.
The pilot kept both hands on the yoke during the incident.
The Airplane Flight Manual contains emergency procedures for autopilot out-of-trim events.
The third item on the emergency checklist directs pilots to re-trim the pitch using the trim wheel if necessary.
The pilot did not attempt to use the manual trim wheel to change the airplane's pitch attitude.
Using the manual trim wheel would have required the pilot to release hand pressure on the control yoke.
The pilot was uncertain when or how the autopilot was disengaged.
The pilot declared an emergency during the incident.
The pilot made a spiraling descent to lose altitude.
The pilot encountered multiple violent pitch up and down oscillations near the bottom of the descent.
The pilot's seat broke during one of the oscillations.
The broken seat allowed the pilot to use his knees to apply forward yoke pressure.
The airplane was "quasi-stable" when the pilot used his knees to control the yoke.
Pitch oscillations still occurred due to the lack of precise pitch control.
The electric nose pitch trim was in the full up position.
The pilot had difficulty controlling the airplane's pitch.
The pilot prepared for an emergency landing.
The pilot used his knees to provide forward yoke pressure during landing.
The airplane landed about 450 feet short of the runway.
The airplane's nose gear collapsed during landing.
The main landing gear were sheared off during landing.
The airplane skidded about 900 feet before coming to rest.
The airplane came to rest to the left of the runway.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Adrian, Michigan

## Date & Time: 
July 27, 2012, 08:46 Local

## Aircraft:
MOONEY AIRPLANE COMPANY, INC. M20TN

## Defining Event:
Inflight upset

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN12FA487

## Registration:
N411JL

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that the airplane, with its autopilot engaged, experienced a "violent pitch-up" without warning while it was climbing through about flight level 180. Extreme forward yoke pressure (the pilot estimated between 100 and 150 pounds force) was required to keep the airplane from pitching up and stalling, so the pilot kept both hands on the yoke.

The Airplane Flight Manual contains emergency procedures for use in the event of an autopilot out-of-trim event; the third item on the checklist directs pilots to re-trim the pitch, if necessary, using the trim wheel. The pilot noted that he did not attempt to use the manual trim wheel to change the airplane's pitch attitude because that would have required him to release hand pressure on the control yoke. He was uncertain when or how the autopilot was disengaged. He declared an emergency and made a spiraling descent to lose altitude. He reported that he encountered multiple violent pitch up and down oscillations near the bottom of the descent; the pilot's seat was broken during one of the oscillations, which allowed the pilot to use his knees to apply forward yoke pressure. He stated that by using his knees to control the yoke, the airplane was "quasi-stable," pitch oscillations still occurred due to the lack of precise pitch control. While still having difficulty controlling the airplane's pitch with the electric nose pitch trim in the full up position, he prepared for an emergency landing. The pilot used his knees to provide forward yoke pressure as he landed the airplane about 450 feet short of the runway. The airplane's nose gear collapsed, the main landing gear were sheared off, and the airplane skidded about 900 feet before coming to rest to the left of the runway.
